thread.title: Sydney vets struggling to meet demand for calicivirus vaccine to protect domestic rabbits - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Sydney vets struggling to meet demand for calicivirus vaccine to protect domestic rabbits - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Jackson Vernon
title: Sydney vets struggling to meet demand for calicivirus vaccine to protect domestic rabbits - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Vets in Sydney's west are running low on a vaccine use to protect domestic rabbits against a new strain of calicivirus, which is being introduced across Australia this week. he Key points: The K-5 strain of the calicivirus will be released nationally Domestic rabbits can also be affected and vaccine stocks are low Farmers hope the new calicivirus strain will curb wild rabbit numbers 
For the first time in 20 years, a new rabbit biocontrol agent will be rolled out nationally in the form of a Korean strain of the calicivirus, known as K-5. 
Authorities have said they were confident the widespread release of the new strain would put a major dent in the rabbit population within weeks. 
However, the calicivirus poses a danger to domestic rabbits and veterinarians are worries about the availability of vaccine stocks. 
The director of the Parramatta Veterinary Hospital, Prue Honson, said veterinarians only have enough the vaccine for the next two weeks. 
"I believe the actual drug company that makes the vaccine is struggling to catch up with all these vets that want all these rabbit vaccines," Ms Honson said. 
Ms Honson said she had been in contact with drug manufacturer Zeotis about when a new batch would arrive. 
"I'd be concerned if they're going to release the virus and we aren't able to keep all our animals vaccinated," she said. 
The ABC contacted the drug manufacturer Zeotis for comment. Keep pets protected: Vets 
The director of Sydney's Exotic and Rabbit Vets David Vella said the vaccine was crucial for protecting domestic rabbits from becoming infected. 
"This virus potentially can cause obviously death in rabbits that are unvaccinated and not protected," he said. 
"The main thing you should do is keep your vaccination up to date. 
"[And] if possible you should be keeping the rabbit in a mosquito proof environment because that is the main way the virus is spread â€” via mosquitos." 
Blue Mountains resident Naomi Whitfield brought her pet rabbit Kenji into Mr Vella's surgery to get vaccinated. 
"We received the notification about the new strain of the calicivirus being released and ... [Kenji is] ... my baby so we wanted to make sure he's protected," she said. 
"The risk is always there so we want to make sure he's protected." Farmers hope virus is successful 
The NSW Department of Primary Industries (DPI) said rabbits were Australia's most significant pest, costing up to $200 million a year in agricultural production losses. 
The DPI's manager for invasive species research John Tracey said the department would monitor numbers before and after the release to measure its effectiveness. 
"Basically what we're looking at is a post count about 30 days, a month, after the initial release," Dr Tracey said. 
The original calicivirus that was released in 1996 killed off about 90 per cent of the rabbit population, but was less effective in cool, wet regions. 
Kevin Edwards, who farms near Orange in central-western New South Wales, said the 1996 release had not been effective locally and he was eager for the latest rollout. 
"I'm really hoping that it is successful, because of the way the virus has worked, they'll take out virtually a whole area," Mr Edwards said. 
Mr Edwards said rabbits were having a crippling impact on producers. 
"Virtually any plants that I plant, they never make it past the seedling stage because they just get ravished by the rabbits," he said.
